questions.question_text: Which of the following NSAP addresses is a private, locally administered address?

discussion.content:
"Official NSAP prefixes are required for CLNS routing. Addresses starting with the value of 49 (AFI = 49) are considered to be private addresses (analogous to RFC 1918 for IP addresses)."

http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=31319&seqNum=2

choices.C: Multiple instances of OSPF for IPv6 can be run on a link.
choices.D: Networks must be explicitly configured using the network command in router OSPF configuration mode.
choices.F: The interface command ipv6 ospf <process-id> area <area-id> is all that is required to enable OSPF for IPv6 on an interface. BCF
choices.E: IPv4 addresses cannot be used as the router ID in OSPF for IPv6.

questions.question_text: Which three statements about configuring OSPF in a IPv6 network are true? (Choose three)

choices.C: Tunneling does not enable users of the new protocol to communicate with users of the old protocol without dual-stack hosts.
choices.B: Tunneling is more difficult to configure than dual stack or translation.
choices.A: Tunneling is less secure than dual stack or translation.
choices.D: Tunneling destinations are manually determined by the IPv4 address in the low-order 32 bits of IPv4-compatible IPv6 addresses. C

questions.answer_description:
Using the tunneling option, organizations build an overlay network that tunnels one protocol over the other by encapsulating IPv6 packets within IPv4 packets and
IPv4 packets within IPv6 packets. The advantage of this approach is that the new protocol can work without disturbing the old protocol, thus providing connectivity between users of the new protocol.
Tunneling has two disadvantages, as discussed in RFC 6144:
✑ Users of the new architecture cannot use the services of the underlying infrastructure.
✑ Tunneling does not enable users of the new protocol to communicate with users of the old protocol without dual-stack hosts, which negates interoperability.
Reference:
http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/ios-nx-os-software/enterprise-ipv6-solution/white_paper_c11-676278.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. The correct answer is C. Tunneling requires dual-stack hosts at the tunnel endpoints to enable communication between IPv4 and IPv6 networks. The tunnel itself just encapsulates one protocol inside the other for transport, but doesn't perform protocol translation.

questions.question_text: Which statement about the use of tunneling to migrate to IPv6 is true?

choices.A: Redistributed routes will have an external type of 1 and a metric of 1.
choices.C: Redistributed routes will maintain their original OSPF routing metric.
choices.D: Redistributed routes will have a default metric of 0 and will be treated as reachable and advertised.
choices.E: Redistributed routes will have a default metric of 0 but will be treated as unreachable and not advertised.
choices.B: Redistributed routes will have an external type of 2 and a metric of 20.

questions.answer_description:
By default, all routes redistributed into OSPF will be tagged as external type 2 (E2) with a metric of 20, except for BGP routes (with a metric of 1).
Note:
The cost of a type 2 route is always the external cost, irrespective of the interior cost to reach that route.
A type 1 cost is the addition of the external cost and the internal cost used to reach that route.

discussion.content: Question about "redistribution of OSPF routes into EIGRP", but answers mean redistribute EIGP into OSPF.
Answer is correct but explanation must be referring to a different question as maximum-paths is irrelevant in this case

questions.answer_description:
By using the "variance 2" command we can share traffic to other feasible successor routes.
But by default, EIGRP only shares traffic to 4 paths. So we need to use the "maximum-paths 6" to make sure all of these routes are used.
